en-us.learning_promise:
**Learning Promise**
In this unit, your students will develop effective problem-solving skills by decomposing problems into smaller parts. They'll use pseudocode as a tool for sequencing actions, use existing code with attributions in order to recognize patterns, systematically identify and fix bugs, and use conditions and compound conditions to program encoded devices.

lessons.lesson_description: Follow a user guide video to replicate the actions of a "quality check" robot.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Congratulations! You’re starting a new business. But you have few tools, few resources, and there’s only so much you can do on your own.  A “quality check” robot has just been delivered to help you make sure you don’t ship something that’s defective. But wait a minute, it needs to be set up! But how? You only have the user manual video to help you.

step.title: Do you read user manuals or watch video tutorials?

text.content:
You've just got a new gadget and you need to set it up. 

How important are step-by-step instructions? Do you prefer videos or booklets?
This robot is your new best friend. It’ll help you check the quality of your ideas… you’ll have it up and running in no time!

comments.comment: This stack will power up your "quality check" robot.

text.content: Play this program and watch your robot power up.

step.title: Create a programming stack from this pseudocode.

text.content:
Program these actions.

* Light up a heart
* When I see the color violet:
>* Light up a smiley
>* Turn motor A 30 degrees
>* Turn motor A -60 degrees
>* Turn motor A 60 degrees
>* Turn motor A -30 degrees
>* Play a sound 
>* Light up a heart

Pseudocode is a way to decompose complex actions into smaller parts. It’s like creating step-by-step instructions.

Your programming stack could look like this:

step.title: Create pseudocode for the rest of the moves.

text.content:
Watch this video now. Decompose all of the actions you see and write pseudocode for the movements.

Create programming stacks that follow your pseudocode.

Think about what you did well and what you could’ve done better.

Now that you know how to break big actions down into smaller ones, you can decompose any problem!

lessons.title: SPIKE Place Your Order
SPIKE Out Of Order
lessons.lesson_description: Find and fix mistakes in a program to make a Delivery Cart work as intended.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: This really isn’t funny! Your delivery cart has gone crazy… it’s bumping into things and isn’t delivering packages.  It’s time to fix it. Are you up for the challenge?

step.title: This is just out of control!

text.content:
When things don't work as planned, you need to find ways to get ‘em back on track.

How do you usually debug things?

This Delivery Cart seriously needs to be fixed. But first, you’ll have to build it.

If you have time, build your own design.

step.title: Play this program to try out your cart.

comments.comment: Here’s the first program you must debug.
Here’s the second program you must debug.

text.content:
It should stop right at the marker. Does it?

If not, fix your program.

This programming stack will make your cart run straight into the marker.

You’ll have to change the distance parameter to a value greater than 0.

code_stack.title: SPIKE Kickstart your business Out of order Step03-Hint
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><variables></variables><block type="flippersensors_isDistance" id=",/?^m!m{Q:ZM,J}8o-*2" x="-27" y="136"><field name="COMPARATOR"><</field><field name="UNIT">cm</field><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flippersensors_distance-sensor-selector" id="`]=r.phB21Q6Ic*uJl=."><field name="field_flippersensors_distance-sensor-selector">B</field></shadow></value><value name="VALUE"><shadow type="math_number" id="8.!57Vv~Y$)b^(ihYaKP"><field name="NUM">10</field></shadow></value></block></xml>

text.content:
Look at the video.

Play the second programming stack and make a list of the 3 bugs you’ll have to fix.

The cart turns in the wrong direction when the Distance Sensor detects the marker.

Inserting a sound or a note into your programming stack can help you detect bugs. If the cart makes the correct movements until you hear a sound, it means the errors are "below" in the stack.

Make changes to your program so that the cart follows this path. 

Use the comment tool to describe your program’s key actions.

What did you do well? Is there anything you could’ve done better?

Hopefully your cart is fixed for good!

lessons.lesson_description: Remix programming stacks to use an X-Y tracking device to follow a path on a piece of paper.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: You’ve shipped your packages. Now you want to know where they are and if they’ve been delivered. No problem! You have a very specialized piece of equipment that can tell you exactly where they are in real time.  Ladies and gentlemen, introducing: the Tracker!

text.content:
Of course everybody wants to know where their packages are. That’s why we use tracking systems.

Can you give an example of a tracking system?

This fabulous piece of tracking system technology will follow the location of your packages in real time. But first, you’ll have to build it:
* Tracker Top
* Tracker Bottom

text.content: Load a sheet of paper into your tracking system and test each of its movements.

The tracker should follow:
* A horizontal line (left-right)
* A vertical line (up-down)

step.title: Track the parcels on the city map.

text.content: Load the city map into your tracking system and combine these programming stacks to follow the route.
You can use the same programming stacks but this time the path has a few tricky parts!

What did you do well? Is there anything you could’ve done better?

Your package has been delivered!

lessons.title: SPIKE Track Your Packages

lessons.lesson_description: Use conditions to lock or unlock the door of a safe-deposit box.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Your packages can never be too safe. Be careful who you give your password to. You never know who could be a crook!

text.content:
Locks and passwords are safety devices that are used everywhere to keep things safe.

Can you give some other examples of safety devices?

This Safe-Deposit Box will help keep your valuables out of the hands of crooks. But first, you’ll have to build it.

If you have time, build your own design!

comments.comment: This stack unlocks the door when the Left Button on the Hub is pressed.

text.content: Play the program to figure out how your Safe-Deposit Box works.

First, the safe will lock.

Press the left button on the Hub to unlock it.

Add a condition to your program.

Make it so your Safe-Deposit Box only opens when the dial has been turned more than 180 degrees clockwise.
Here’s an example of a condition:

code_stack.title: SPIKE Kickstart your business Keep-it-safe Step04-Hint
code_stack.xml: <xml xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"><variables></variables><block type="control_wait_until" id="z:B9z7DRZ;CUsm1bhP`a" x="-16" y="125"><value name="CONDITION"><block type="operator_gt" id="KJ6|PlR88(AMaK5hO6mE"><value name="OPERAND1"><shadow type="text" id="a)$$(G28-yd:KZ|=pL{f"><field name="TEXT"></field></shadow><block type="flippermoremotor_position" id=";X(AOnvr/o5N*aCg[aQN"><value name="PORT"><shadow type="flippermoremotor_single-motor-selector" id="Xjc,g^C?neF0K1]P$G*/"><field name="field_flippermoremotor_single-motor-selector">B</field></shadow></value></block></value><value name="OPERAND2"><shadow type="text" id="[uK(}7mHy9kpX06bp:WE"><field name="TEXT">180</field></shadow></value></block></value></block></xml>

text.content:
Modify your program to work like the dial on a safe. For example, to open, the dial must turn:
* 180 degrees clockwise
* 90 degrees counterclockwise
* 180 degrees clockwise

Think about what you did well and how you could improve for next time.

Your package is in good hands!

lessons.title: SPIKE Keep It Safe

lessons.lesson_description: Use compound conditions to reinforce the encryption pattern on a safe-deposit box.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Whoa! You’ve been hacked. It's definitely time to up your security. Looks like you’re gonna need a multiple conditions password system.

text.content:
Someone hacked the Safe-Deposit Box!

How can you make it more secure?

reduced_palette.title: SPIKE Kickstart Keep it really safe

text.content:
New version: bigger, stronger, safer!

If you have time, build your own design!

comments.comment: This stack locks the door and starts the extra protection mechanism.
This stack unlocks the door if you press the Left Button on the Hub within 5 seconds.

text.content: Play the program to figure out how your Super-Safe-Deposit Box works.

First, the safe will lock.

Press the left button on the Hub to unlock it.

You only get five seconds to press the left button!

step.title: Time to add another layer of security.

text.content:
Add a compound condition to your program.

Make it so your Super-Safe-Deposit Box only opens when the dial has been turned more than 180 degrees OR the right button is pressed.

Compare the security of the 2 programs. 

Which is the safer way to go?
Create your own secret sequence using compound conditions and have someone else try to unlock your Super-Safe-Deposit Box.

What did you do well? Is there something you could’ve done better?

BOOM! Hackerproof.

lessons.title: SPIKE Keep It Really Safe

lessons.lesson_description: Create and program an automated helper that can identify and ship the correct package based on color.
lessons.student_worksheet_description: Well, it sure looks like you’re successful! Now you have to deal with even more orders and more packages. You really need to keep up! But how?

text.content:
Yikes! There are tons of packages that need to be delivered to the right place… and quickly.

How can you speed up the the shipping process?

You have to design, build, and program a factory robot that can identify and ship the correct package based on color. But first, you’ll need some packages.
* Packages

Come up with at least 3 things your automated helper will need to do.
Think about:
* Ways your robot can sense different locations
* Ways your robot can sort colored packages

Other possible actions could be:
* Safely rejecting a wrong package
* Informing if no box is detected
* Communicating that it’s “waiting for an order”

Visit the building instructions page for inspiration.
Pick the best idea and start building! Put LEGO® bricks together to create your prototype.

Now program your robot’s actions. 

Use pseudocode to guide you through coding all the things you’ve agreed your factory robot needs to do.

Make sure to document your bugs and how you’ve solved them.

Program one action at a time, then make sure it works before moving onto the next one.

It’s ok to reuse programs from your earlier projects.
Present your automated helper to potential investors and describe why it’s an awesome investment opportunity.

Are you pleased with your performance? Is there anything you could’ve done better?

**Congratulations! Your business is now in good hands!**

lessons.title: SPIKE Automate It

en-us.title: SPIKE Kickstart A Business
en-us.unit_plan_description: You’ve come up with an amazing idea and you want to share it with everybody. Entrepreneurship can strike at any moment, so get ready to transform your thoughts into reality.
